raw_text: At ACL 2000, Brill and Moore (2000) introduced a new error model, allowing generic string-to-string edits
clean_text: At ACL 2000, Brill and Moore (2000) introduced a new error model, allowing generic string-to-string edits.

raw_text: We do not pursue this, here, however. Brill and Moore (2000) present an improved error model for noisy channel spelling correction that goes beyond single insertions, deletions, substitutions, and transpositions
clean_text: Brill and Moore (2000) present an improved error model for noisy channel spelling correction that goes beyond single insertions, deletions, substitutions, and transpositions.

raw_text: Brilland Moore (2000) showed that adding a source language model increases the accuracy significantly

raw_text: The error model LTR was trained exactly as described originally by Brill and Moore (2000)
clean_text: The error model LTR was trained exactly as described originally by Brill and Moore (2000).

citing_paper_authors: Sergey, Gubanov | Irina, Galinskaya | Alexey, Baytin
raw_text: In baseline speller we use a substring-based error model P dist (q 0? q 1) described in (Brill and Moore, 2000), the error model training method and the hypotheses generator are similar to (Duan and Hsu, 2011)
clean_text: In baseline speller we use a substring-based error model P dist (q0|q1) described in (Brill and Moore, 2000), the error model training method and the hypotheses generator are similar to (Duan and Hsu, 2011).

raw_text: Brill and Moore (2000 )characterise the error model by computing the product of operation probabilities on slice-by-slice string edits
clean_text: Brill and Moore (2000) characterise the error model by computing the product of operation probabilities on slice-by-slice string edits.

raw_text: The next class of approaches applied the noisy channel model to correct single word spelling errors (Kernighan et al., 1990), (Brill and Moore, 2000)
clean_text: The next class of approaches applied the noisy channel model to correct single word spelling errors (Kernighan et al., 1990), (Brill and Moore, 2000).

raw_text: Neither do we require pairs of misspelled names and their correct spellings for learning the error model unlike (Brill and Moore, 2000) or large-coverage general purpose lexicon for unlike (Cucerzan and Brill, 2004) or pronunciation dictionaries unlike (Toutanova and Moore, 2002)
clean_text: Neither do we require pairs of misspelled names and their correct spellings for learning the error model unlike (Brill and Moore, 2000) or large-coverage general purpose lexicon for unlike (Cucerzan and Brill, 2004) or pronunciation dictionaries unlike (Toutanova and Moore, 2002).

raw_text: Brill and Moore (2000) learn misspelled-word to correctly-spelled-word similarities for spelling correction
clean_text: Brill and Moore (2000) learn misspelled-word to correctly-spelled-word similarities for spelling correction.

raw_text: For example, Brill and Moore (2000) combine a character-based alignment with the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm to develop animproved probabilistic error model for spelling correction
clean_text: For example, Brill and Moore (2000) combine a character-based alignment with the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm to develop an improved probabilistic error model for spelling correction.

clean_text: The largest step towards an automatically trainable spelling system was the statistical model for spelling errors (Brill and Moore, 2000).

clean_text: Contrary to Brill and Moore (2000), we observe that user edits of ten have both left and right context, when editing a document.

raw_text: The perfect score function calculates the probability of a suggestion given the misspelled word (Brill and Moore, 2000)
clean_text: The perfect score function calculates the probability of a suggestion given the misspelled word (Brill and Moore, 2000).

citing_paper_authors: Hisami, Suzuki | Xiao, Li | Jianfeng, Gao
raw_text: In addition to the simple Levenshtein distance, we also use generalized string-to-string edit distance (Brill and Moore, 2000), which we trained on aligned katakana-English word pairs in the same manner as Brill et al (2001)
clean_text: In addition to the simple Levenshtein distance, we also use generalized string-to-string edit distance (Brill and Moore, 2000), which we trained on aligned katakana-English word pairs in the same manner as Brill et al (2001).

citing_paper_authors: Hisami, Suzuki | Xiao, Li | Jianfeng, Gao
raw_text: One interesting future avenue to consider is to use the edit distance functions in our current model to select a subset of query-candidate pairs that are similar in terms of these functions, separately for the surface and Romanized forms, and use this subset to align the character strings in these query-candidate pairs as described in Brill and Moore (2000), and add the edit operations derived in this manner to the term variation identification classifier as features
clean_text: One interesting future avenue to consider is to use the edit distance functions in our current model to select a subset of query-candidate pairs that are similar in terms of these functions, separately for the surface and Romanized forms, and use this subset to align the character strings in these query-candidate pairs as described in Brill and Moore (2000), and add the edit operations derived in this manner to the term variation identification classifier as features.

raw_text: Brill and Moore (2000) introduced a model that worked on character sequences, not only on character level, and was conditioned on where in the word the sequences occurred
clean_text: Brill and Moore (2000) introduced a model that worked on character sequences, not only on character level, and was conditioned on where in the word the sequences occurred.

raw_text: The approximate string matching algorithm we suggest is essentially that of Brill and Moore (2000), a modified weighted Levenshtein distance, where we allow error operations on character sequences as well as on single characters
clean_text: The approximate string matching algorithm we suggest is essentially that of Brill and Moore (2000), a modified weighted Levenshtein distance, where we allow error operations on character sequences as well as on single characters.

citing_paper_authors: Qing, Chen | Mu, Li | Ming, Zhou
raw_text: (Brill and Moore, 2000) presented an improved error model over the one proposed by (Kernighan et al, 1990) by allowing generic string-to-string edit operations, which helps with modeling major cognitive errors such as the confusion between le and al. Via explicit modeling of phonetic information of English words, (Toutanova and Moore, 2002) further investigated this issue
clean_text: (Brill and Moore, 2000) presented an improved error model over the one proposed by (Kernighan et al, 1990) by allowing generic string-to-string edit operations, which helps with modeling major cognitive errors such as the confusion between le and al.

raw_text: Thesecondis a slightly modified version of the spelling correction model of Brill and Moore (2000) .3 This model allows many-to-many edit operations, which makes P (liter|litre)? P (l 7? l) P (i7? i) P (tre7 ?ter) possible
